isis.stitle: REPAIR INSTRUCTIONS FOR FIBERGLASS AND PLASTIC (ABS) MATERIAL - FIBERGLASS - STRUCTURAL REPAIRS

svcprocinfo.para: The procedures given under Structural Repairs are used for repairing various types of damage to the fiberglass laminate - cracks, large and small fractures, panel separation, etc. - that can affect the structural soundness of the laminate.

warning.para: FIBERGLASS ABS PLASTIC REPAIRS: To avoid breathing dust and fumes, wear approved protective equipment. Breathing fiberglass ABS plastic dust and/or fumes can be hazardous to your health.

para.emph: 1. OSHA standards should be consulted with respect to mandatory requirements as well as suggested procedures to minimize exposure. (Reference: Title 29, Code of Federal Regulations, Section 1910, 1001.)
2. Whenever possible work on fiber- glass and ABS plastics in a separate area away from other operations.

warning.para: 3. Always wear a respirator approved by NIOSH or MSHA during all fiberglass or ABS plastic repairs.
4. Worker clean-up. Wash your hands before eating, drinking or smoking.

svcsubproc.title: Cracks, Small and Large Fractures
svcsubproc.para: Cracks, small fractures and large fractures are identified as follows:

A crack is an obvious separation extending completely through the laminate ( Figure 16). Cracks, which result from stress beyond normal operation, can occur in the center of the laminate or extend from the laminate edge.

figure.caption: Figure 16. Crack Extends Through Laminate

svcsubproc.para: Small fractures are punctures that are 3 inches or less in size ( Figure 17).

figure.caption: Figure 17. Small Fractures Are 3 Inches or Less in Size

svcsubproc.para: Large fractures are punctures that are 3 inches or more in length ( Figure 18).

figure.caption: Figure 18. Large Fractures are 3 Inches or More in Size

svcsubproc.para: Cracks, small fractures and large fractures are repaired following the same basic procedure. All require backing patches or backup strips. These are simple laminates that are formed to the shape of the surface being repaired and bonded with epoxy cement to the back side of the repair area. The backing patch serves two functions:

step1.para: It provides the foundation on which the exterior surface is built up and formed to match the original contour.
It provides the mechanical strength needed to keep a repair structurally and visually intact during normal operation and use.

svcsubproc.para: A repaired laminate must be as strong as the original material surrounding it. If it is not, the repair will not last and is likely to crack around the edge of the patch.
In addition to the backing patch, large fractures will require additional mat laminations which are used as a filler in building up the surface to the original contour.
Perform the steps listed under PREPARATION PROCEDURE, then proceed with the repair as follows:

step1.para: Using a tapered bit or a saber saw, remove the cracked and flaked fiberglass surrounding the damaged area. For cracks, remove enough material so that there is an open gap at least 1/8 inch (3.2 mm) wide ( Figure 19). For small and large fractures, cut away as much material as is required to provide a solid edge ( Figure 20 and Figure 21).

figure.caption: Figure 19. Remove Cracked and Flaked Fiberglass Surrounding Damaged Area
Figure 20. Cut Away Enough Material to Provide Solid Edge
Figure 21. Cut Away Enough Material to Provide Solid Edge

step1.para: If panel is out of alignment, re-align it with C-clamps or other clamping device ( Figure 22).

figure.caption: Figure 22. Re-Align Panel With C-Clamps

step1.para: Mask off undamaged surface, leaving a working area of approximately 5 inches (127 mm) surrounding the damaged area ( Figure 23).

figure.caption: Figure 23. Mask Off Undamaged Surface

note.para: Steps 4 through 10 describe the procedure for forming a backing patch using the outside surface of the damaged area. If the inner surface of the damaged area is accessible, it is preferable to form the patch to the inner surface in the same manner.

step1.para: Cut a piece of plastic separating film large enough to extend approximately 3 inches (76 mm) beyond the edge of the repair area. Tape the film to the outside repair surface ( Figure 24).

figure.caption: Figure 24. Cut Piece of Plastic Separating Film

step1.para: Then, using a cardboard template ( Figure 25), cut the required pieces of mat large enough to extend 2 inches (51 mm) beyond the edges of the repair area.

figure.caption: Figure 25. Use Cardboard Template to Cut Required Pieces of Mat

note.para: The number of layers of mat used in the backing patch depends on the thickness of the body panel being repaired. Refer to Chart 1 to determine the number of layers required. The original fiberglass parts are normally 0.100 in. (2.5 mm) thick. Therefore, the minimum backing patch thickness must be 0.126 in. (3.2 mm) or three layers of 1-1/2 oz. (42g) mat.

entry.para: LAYERS OF FIBERGLASS MAT REQUIRED FOR PATCH

step1.para: Mix the recommended amount of polyester resin according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Apply some resin to the working area of the separating film ( Figure 26).

figure.caption: Figure 26. Apply Resin to Working Area of Separating Film

step1.para: Soak the first layer of mat in resin; then place it over the repair area and allow it to harden slightly.
Now lay-up by hand the remaining piece or pieces of resin-soaked mat ( Figure 27).

figure.caption: Figure 27. Lay-Up Remaining Pieces of Resin-Soaked Mat

note.para: To prevent the patch from sliding on a vertical surface, tape a piece of plastic film over the patch.

step1.para: Allow the patch to harden; then pop it off ( Figure 28) and remove the separating film.

figure.caption: Figure 28. Remove Separating Film

step1.para: Working from the outside and using a file or grinder, taper the edges of the damaged area at an angle of no more than 45 degrees ( Figure 29).

figure.caption: Figure 29. Taper Edges of Damaged Area

step1.para: Remove flaky edges and feather the painted surface back about 1/2 inch (13 mm) beyond the damaged area by hand-sanding or power-sanding with 360 grit sandpaper ( Figure 30).

figure.caption: Figure 30. Remove Flaky Edges and Feather Painted Surface Back

step1.para: Clean the area with a dry cloth or air.

Sand the underside of the repair area with 80 grit (or less) sandpaper to create a rough bonding surface approximately 2 inches (51 mm) from the center of a crack ( Figure 31) or 2 inches (51 mm) back from the edge of a fracture.

figure.caption: Figure 31. Sand Underside of Repair Area

step1.para: Trim the perimeter and sand the mating surface of the backing patch ( Figure 32) with 80 grit sandpaper (or less), checking for smooth fit to the underside. Clean all surfaces with air.

figure.caption: Figure 32. Sand Mating Surface of Backing Patch

step1.para: Now determine a method of holding the backing patch in place (C-clamps, self-tapping screws, etc.) and trial test the method ( Figure 33).

figure.caption: Figure 33. Determine Method of Holding Backing Patch in Place

note.para: If you use self-tapping screws, predrill the holes. Then before finishing the surface, remove the screws and fill the holes with body filler.

step1.para: Mix epoxy adhesive according to the instructions.
Apply the adhesive to underside of the repair area and also to the patch ( Figure 34). Press patch in place until epoxy squeezes out from all edges.

figure.caption: Figure 34. Apply Adhesive to Underside of Repair Area

step1.para: Hold backing patch with clamps or screws and allow the adhesive to harden for the time given in the manufacturer's instructions ( Figure 35).

figure.caption: Figure 35. Hold Backing Patch With Clamps or Screws

note.para: If the adhesive is squeezed into the tapered groove or hole during bonding, clean it out before the adhesive sets, and roughen any remaining adhesive with 360 grit sandpaper after it hardens.

step1.para: Steps 20 through 23 apply for large fractures only. For cracks or small fractures, omit steps 20 through 23 and go on to step 24.
While the adhesive is hardening, cut some pieces of mat to fit into the hole in the panel ( Figure 36). The mat is not a structural reinforcement, but a filler.

figure.caption: Figure 36. Cut Pieces of Mat to Fit Hole in Panel

note.para: Cut enough pieces of mat which when layered will fill the hole to just below the surface of the original panel.

step1.para: Following the manufacturer's instructions, mix enough resin to saturate the piece(s) of mat.
Using a stippling motion of your brush, lay-up the resin-soaked mat by hand ( Figure 37), one piece at a time, until the top layer is just below the surface of the panel.

figure.caption: Figure 37. Lay-Up Resin-Soaked Mat By Hand

step1.para: Allow the mat to harden. Then, rough sand with 80 grit sandpaper ( Figure 38).

figure.caption: Figure 38. Rough Sand Mat

step1.para: To complete the repair, use the procedure for SURFACE FILLING AND FINISHING.
